clinical_study.brief_title: Cognitive Behavior Therapy (CBT) and Psychological Status and Immune Function
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Cognitive Behavior Therapy (CBT) on Psychological Status and Immune Function of Patient Undergoing Colorectal Cancer Surgery and Primary Caregivers.

brief_summary.textblock: To explore the effect of CBT on psychological status of patient undergoing colorectal cancer surgery and primary caregivers. To explore the effect of CBT on immune function of patient undergoing colorectal cancer surgery and primary caregivers.

detailed_description.textblock: Cancer patients and their primary caregivers are often subjected to considerable psychological stress. CBT is considered as one of the effective methods to relieve stress. CBT is effective in alleviating depression and anxiety, but the effect of CBT on cognitive and immune function in patients with colorectal cancer and their primary caregivers remains uninvestigated.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline stress perception at follow-up.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and follow-up ( immediately after intervention, 3 months and 6 months after intervention).
primary_outcome.description: Stress perception will be assessed by Perceived Stress Scale (PSS-10). The sum score of PSS-10 ranges from 0 to 40. Higher scores mean a worse outcome.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline depressionat at follow-up.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and follow-up ( immediately after intervention, 3 months and 6 months after intervention).
primary_outcome.description: Depression will be assessed by Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9). The sum score of PHQ-9 ranges from 0 to 27. Higher scores mean a worse outcome.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline anxiety at follow-up.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and follow-up ( immediately after intervention, 3 months and 6 months after intervention).
primary_outcome.description: Anxiety will be assessed by Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD-7). The sum score of GAD-7 ranges from 0 to 21. Higher scores mean a worse outcome.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline cognitive function at follow-up.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and follow-up ( immediately after intervention, 3 months and 6 months after intervention).
primary_outcome.description: Cognitive function will be assessed by Mini-mental State Examination (MMSE), Hopkins Verbal Learning Test-Revised, Digit Span Test, Digit-symbol Test and Trail Making Test.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline immune function at follow-up.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and follow-up ( immediately after intervention, 3 months and 6 months after intervention).
primary_outcome.description: Immune function assessment includes cytokine levels (IL-1α, IL-1β, IL-6, IL-8, TNF-α, TNF-β, CRP) and immune cell levels (CD4+T cell, CD8+T cell, natural killer, monocytes, B cell).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline quality of life of patient at follow-up.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and follow-up ( immediately after intervention, 3 months and 6 months after intervention).
secondary_outcome.description: It will be assessed by European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire-Colorectal Cancer 29 (EORTC QLQ-CR29).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline quality of life of primary caregivers at follow-up.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and follow-up ( immediately after intervention, 3 months and 6 months after intervention).
secondary_outcome.description: It will be assessed by Caregivers Quality of Life Cancer-Index (CQOL-C).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline caregiver burden at follow-up.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and follow-up ( immediately after intervention, 3 months and 6 months after intervention).
secondary_outcome.description: It will be assessed by Zarit Caregiver Burden Interview (ZBI).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline sleep quality at follow-up.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and follow-up ( immediately after intervention, 3 months and 6 months after intervention).
secondary_outcome.description: It will be assessed by Pittsburgh sleep quality index (PSQI).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline self efficacy at follow-up.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and follow-up ( immediately after intervention, 3 months and 6 months after intervention).
secondary_outcome.description: It will be assessed by General Self Efficacy (GSES). The sum score of General Self Efficacy ranges from 10 to 40. Higher scores mean a better outcome.
It will be assessed by Social Support Rating Scale (SSRS). The sum score of Social Support Rating Scale ranges from 12 to 66. Higher scores mean a better outcome.

arm_group.description: Patients and primary caregivers randomly assigned to CBT group will receive 10 times of CBT treatment before and after surgery.

Patients and primary caregivers randomly assigned to non-CBT group will receive four sessions of health education in a month after surgery. Each session will last 1 hour, including lectures and Q&A . The content of each session is different, including: diagnosis and treatment of colorectal cancer, postoperative adverse reactions and management of colorectal cancer, nutritional support after colorectal cancer surgery and physical exercise after colorectal cancer surgery.

intervention.description: The CBT intervention is a 10-times group-based intervention that meets monthly for 1.5 hours. Our CBT intervention is designed to be conducted in groups of six to eight patients led by two group facilitators. The first session will be done a week before surgery, and the next nine sessions will be done a week before chemical therapy. Group leaders will: guide participants relaxation training, develop a supportive group environment, encourage emotional expression, assist participants develop a sense of self-confidence, identify maladaptive coping and encourage adaptive coping responses.
